pages.name: Why Hand Hygiene Matters
content: Hand hygiene is the single most important measure to prevent healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). It is a simple, effective, and cost-efficient intervention that protects both patients and healthcare workers.

GLOBAL BURDEN OF HAIs: Healthcare-associated infections affect millions of patients worldwide each year, leading to increased morbidity, mortality, prolonged hospital stays, and substantial healthcare costs. Studies show that 20-40% of HAIs are preventable through proper hand hygiene.

TRANSMISSION PATHWAYS: When healthcare workers fail to clean their hands at critical moments, they can transmit pathogens from one patient to another, from contaminated surfaces to patients, or from patients to themselves. This transmission chain is the primary mechanism for spreading infections in healthcare settings.

CLINICAL AND ECONOMIC IMPACT: HAIs affect approximately 1 in 31 hospital patients on any given day in the United States. These infections result in tens of thousands of deaths annually and cost billions of dollars in additional healthcare expenses. The CDC estimates that HAIs cost the U.S. healthcare system $28-45 billion annually.

PROVEN EFFECTIVENESS: Improving hand hygiene compliance has been shown to reduce HAI rates by 30-50% in multiple studies. This translates to fewer patient complications, shorter hospital stays, reduced antibiotic use, and lower healthcare costs. A 2024 systematic review confirmed that multimodal hand hygiene interventions consistently reduce HAI rates across diverse healthcare settings.

HEALTHCARE WORKER PROTECTION: Hand hygiene also protects healthcare workers from acquiring infections from patients. Many pathogens, including multidrug-resistant organisms (MDROs), can colonize healthcare workers' hands and potentially cause infection if transmitted to mucous membranes or breaks in skin.

PANDEMIC PREPAREDNESS: The COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the critical importance of hand hygiene in preventing respiratory infections. Hand hygiene, combined with other infection prevention measures, remains a cornerstone of pandemic preparedness and response. WHO's 2024 guidance emphasizes hand hygiene as a fundamental component of global health security.
keyPoints: Hand hygiene is the single most important measure to prevent HAIs
20-40% of HAIs are preventable through proper hand hygiene
Improving compliance reduces HAI rates by 30-50%
Protects both patients and healthcare workers
Cost-effective intervention with significant impact on patient safety
HAIs cost U.S. healthcare system $28-45 billion annually

pages.name: WHO 5 Moments for Hand Hygiene
content: The WHO 5 Moments for Hand Hygiene is a globally recognized framework that defines the key moments when healthcare workers should perform hand hygiene during patient care. This approach is based on the concept of patient zones and helps healthcare workers understand when hand hygiene is critical to prevent pathogen transmission.

The framework divides the healthcare environment into two zones: the patient zone (patient and their immediate surroundings) and the healthcare area (everything outside the patient zone). Understanding these zones is essential for applying the 5 Moments correctly.

MOMENT 1: BEFORE TOUCHING A PATIENT - Perform hand hygiene before entering the patient zone and touching the patient. This protects the patient from harmful germs carried on your hands. Example: Before performing a physical examination, taking vital signs, or providing comfort care.

MOMENT 2: BEFORE CLEAN/ASEPTIC PROCEDURE - Perform hand hygiene immediately before any aseptic task or handling invasive medical devices. This protects the patient from harmful germs, including their own, from entering their body. Examples: Before inserting a urinary catheter, performing wound care, preparing injections, or handling IV lines.

MOMENT 3: AFTER BODY FLUID EXPOSURE RISK - Perform hand hygiene immediately after any task where exposure to body fluids has occurred or is possible, even if gloves were worn. This protects you and the healthcare environment from harmful patient germs. Examples: After contact with blood, urine, feces, wound drainage, mucous membranes, or non-intact skin.

MOMENT 4: AFTER TOUCHING A PATIENT - Perform hand hygiene after touching a patient and before leaving the patient zone. This protects you and the healthcare environment from harmful patient germs. Example: After assisting a patient with mobility, bathing, or any direct patient contact.

MOMENT 5: AFTER TOUCHING PATIENT SURROUNDINGS - Perform hand hygiene after touching any object or furniture in the patient's immediate surroundings, even without touching the patient. This protects you and the healthcare environment from harmful patient germs. Examples: After touching bed rails, bedside tables, monitors, IV pumps, or call buttons.

The 5 Moments framework applies to all healthcare settings, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, outpatient clinics, and home healthcare. It is designed to be simple, memorable, and applicable to diverse clinical situations.

Healthcare workers may need to perform hand hygiene multiple times during a single patient encounter if they move between different moments. For example, a nurse might perform hand hygiene before touching a patient (Moment 1), before inserting an IV catheter (Moment 2), after the procedure if blood exposure occurred (Moment 3), and after touching the patient (Moment 4).
keyPoints: WHO 5 Moments is the global standard for hand hygiene timing
Based on patient zone vs. healthcare area concept
Moment 1: Before touching a patient (protect patient)
Moment 2: Before clean/aseptic procedure (protect patient from own germs)
Moment 3: After body fluid exposure risk (protect self and environment)
Moment 4: After touching a patient (protect self and environment)
Moment 5: After touching patient surroundings (protect self and environment)
Multiple hand hygiene actions may be needed during one patient encounter

pages.name: Hand Hygiene Methods Overview
content: There are three primary methods of hand hygiene in healthcare settings: alcohol-based hand sanitizer (ABHS), handwashing with soap and water, and surgical hand antisepsis. Each method has specific indications, techniques, and advantages.

ALCOHOL-BASED HAND SANITIZER (ABHS): This is the preferred method for hand hygiene in most clinical situations. ABHS products contain 60-95% alcohol (ethanol or isopropanol) and are more effective at killing most healthcare-associated pathogens than soap and water. ABHS is faster, more convenient, causes less skin irritation, and improves hand hygiene compliance.

ABHS is effective against most bacteria (including MRSA and VRE), viruses (including influenza, coronavirus, and norovirus), and fungi. However, ABHS is NOT effective against bacterial spores such as Clostridioides difficile or certain non-enveloped viruses when present in high numbers.

HANDWASHING WITH SOAP AND WATER: This method is required in specific situations where ABHS is not appropriate. Soap and water physically removes dirt, organic material, and some microorganisms from hands through mechanical action and rinsing. Plain soap is adequate for most situations, though antimicrobial soap may be used in specific settings.

Handwashing with soap and water is REQUIRED when: hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with blood or body fluids; before eating; after using the restroom; during outbreaks of C. difficile or norovirus (as an additional precaution); and after caring for patients with known or suspected C. difficile infection during outbreaks.

SURGICAL HAND ANTISEPSIS: This is a specialized hand hygiene procedure performed before donning sterile gloves for surgical or invasive procedures. The goal is to eliminate transient flora and reduce resident skin flora for the duration of the procedure. Surgical hand antisepsis can be performed using either antimicrobial soap scrub (2-6 minutes) or alcohol-based surgical hand rub with persistent activity.

COMPARISON OF METHODS: ABHS is faster (20 seconds vs. 40-60 seconds for handwashing), more effective against most pathogens, less damaging to skin, and more accessible at point of care. However, handwashing is necessary when hands are visibly soiled and provides mechanical removal of spores and certain pathogens that ABHS cannot kill.

The choice of hand hygiene method should be based on the clinical situation, the presence of visible soiling, and the type of pathogen suspected. In most routine patient care situations, ABHS is the preferred method. Healthcare facilities should ensure both ABHS and handwashing facilities are readily available to healthcare workers.
keyPoints: Three methods: ABHS, soap and water, surgical hand antisepsis
ABHS is preferred for most clinical situations (faster, more effective, less irritating)
ABHS contains 60-95% alcohol and kills most pathogens except spores
Soap and water required when hands visibly soiled, before eating, after restroom, during C. diff/norovirus outbreaks
Surgical hand antisepsis uses antimicrobial soap (2-6 min) or alcohol-based surgical hand rub
Both ABHS and handwashing facilities should be readily available

pages.name: Alcohol-Based Hand Rub (ABHS) Technique
content: Proper technique is essential for alcohol-based hand sanitizer to be effective. The WHO recommends a 6-step technique that ensures all surfaces of the hands are covered with the product.

STEP 1: APPLY PRODUCT - Apply a palmful (3-5 mL) of alcohol-based hand rub to cupped dry hands. The amount should be sufficient to cover all surfaces of both hands. If hands feel dry before 20 seconds, you likely used too little product.
STEP 2: RUB PALMS TOGETHER - Rub palm to palm with fingers together in a circular motion. This covers the palmar surfaces of both hands.
STEP 3: RUB BETWEEN FINGERS - Place right palm over left dorsum with interlaced fingers and rub, then repeat with left palm over right dorsum. This covers the backs of hands and between fingers.
STEP 4: RUB PALM TO PALM WITH FINGERS INTERLACED - Rub palm to palm with fingers interlaced to ensure coverage between all fingers.
STEP 5: RUB BACKS OF FINGERS - Place backs of fingers to opposing palms with fingers interlocked and rub. This ensures the backs of fingers are covered.

STEP 6: RUB THUMBS AND FINGERTIPS - Rotational rubbing of left thumb clasped in right palm and vice versa. Then rub fingertips of each hand in opposite palm in a circular motion. These areas are frequently missed.

DURATION: Continue rubbing hands together, covering all surfaces, until hands are completely dry. This should take approximately 20 seconds. Do NOT rinse or wipe hands before they are dry, as this reduces effectiveness.
AREAS FREQUENTLY MISSED: Studies using fluorescent markers show that thumbs, fingertips, and areas between fingers are most commonly missed during hand hygiene. Pay special attention to these areas.

WHEN TO USE ABHS: Use ABHS for hand hygiene in all clinical situations EXCEPT when hands are visibly soiled, before eating, after using the restroom, or during C. difficile/norovirus outbreaks. ABHS should be used immediately before touching a patient, before aseptic procedures, after body fluid exposure (if hands not visibly soiled), after touching a patient, and after touching patient surroundings.

PRODUCT VOLUME: Using adequate product volume is critical. Most dispensers deliver 1.5-3 mL per pump. You may need 2 pumps to achieve adequate coverage. If your hands feel dry before 20 seconds, you used too little product.
keyPoints: Apply palmful (3-5 mL) to dry hands
Follow WHO 6-step technique to cover all surfaces
Rub until completely dry (~20 seconds)
Pay special attention to thumbs, fingertips, and between fingers (frequently missed)
Do NOT rinse or wipe before hands are dry
Use adequate product volume (may need 2 pumps)

pages.name: Soap and Water Technique
content: Handwashing with soap and water is required when hands are visibly soiled, before eating, after using the restroom, and during outbreaks of C. difficile or norovirus. Proper technique ensures effective removal of dirt, organic material, and microorganisms.
STEP 1: WET HANDS - Wet hands with clean running water (warm or cold). Avoid using hot water, as it increases skin irritation and dryness without improving antimicrobial efficacy.

STEP 2: APPLY SOAP - Apply the manufacturer-recommended amount of soap to hands. Plain soap is adequate for most situations. Antimicrobial soap may be used in specific settings but offers no additional benefit for routine handwashing.

STEP 3: LATHER AND SCRUB - Rub hands together vigorously to create lather. Scrub all surfaces of hands and fingers for at least 15-20 seconds. Cover the same areas as ABHS technique: palms, backs of hands, between fingers, backs of fingers, thumbs, and fingertips.

STEP 4: SCRUB UNDER NAILS - Pay special attention to areas under fingernails and around nail beds, as these areas harbor high concentrations of microorganisms. Use a nail cleaner if available, especially before surgical procedures.

STEP 5: RINSE THOROUGHLY - Rinse hands thoroughly under clean running water to remove all soap and loosened microorganisms. Ensure all soap residue is removed, as residual soap can cause skin irritation.

STEP 6: DRY HANDS - Dry hands thoroughly using a disposable paper towel. Pat rather than rub to minimize skin irritation. Ensure hands are completely dry, as moist hands transfer microorganisms more easily than dry hands.

STEP 7: TURN OFF FAUCET - Use the disposable towel to turn off the faucet to avoid recontaminating clean hands. Discard the towel in a waste receptacle without touching the receptacle with your hands.

DURATION: The entire handwashing process should take 40-60 seconds. Some guidelines recommend scrubbing for at least 20 seconds (the time it takes to sing 'Happy Birthday' twice). The focus should be on thorough coverage of all hand surfaces rather than exact timing.

WHEN SOAP AND WATER IS REQUIRED: Hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with blood/body fluids; before eating; after using the restroom; during outbreaks of C. difficile or norovirus; after caring for patients with known or suspected C. difficile infection during outbreaks.

SOAP SELECTION: Plain soap is adequate for routine handwashing. Antimicrobial soap (containing chlorhexidine, triclosan, or other antiseptic agents) may be used in specific settings such as surgical hand antisepsis, but offers no additional benefit for routine handwashing and may contribute to antimicrobial resistance.
keyPoints: Wet hands with clean water (avoid hot water)
Apply soap and lather for 15-20 seconds
Scrub all surfaces: palms, backs, between fingers, thumbs, fingertips, under nails
Rinse thoroughly to remove all soap
Dry completely with disposable towel (pat, don't rub)
Use towel to turn off faucet
Total process: 40-60 seconds
Required when hands visibly soiled, before eating, after restroom, during C. diff/norovirus outbreaks

pages.name: Surgical Hand Antisepsis
content: Surgical hand antisepsis is performed before donning sterile gloves for surgical or other invasive procedures. The goal is to eliminate transient flora and reduce resident skin flora on the hands and forearms for the duration of the procedure, minimizing the risk of surgical site infection if gloves are punctured or torn.

PRE-SCRUB PREPARATION: Before beginning surgical hand antisepsis, remove all jewelry including rings, watches, and bracelets. Jewelry harbors microorganisms and interferes with effective hand antisepsis. Ensure fingernails are short (not extending past fingertip) and free of artificial nails or nail polish.

NAIL CLEANING: Clean under fingernails using a nail cleaner under running water. This step is critical, as the subungual area (under nails) harbors the highest concentration of microorganisms on hands. Use a single-use disposable nail cleaner.

METHOD 1: ANTIMICROBIAL SOAP SCRUB - Wet hands and forearms with water. Apply the manufacturer-recommended amount of antimicrobial soap (containing chlorhexidine gluconate, povidone-iodine, or other approved antiseptic). Scrub hands and forearms for the length of time recommended by the manufacturer, typically 2-6 minutes. Longer scrub times (e.g., 10 minutes) are not necessary and may damage skin.

SCRUB TECHNIQUE: Using a systematic approach, scrub all surfaces of hands and forearms up to the elbows. Divide each hand and forearm into sections (fingers, palm, back of hand, wrist, forearm) and scrub each section for a specified time. Keep hands elevated above elbows during scrubbing to allow water to flow from cleanest area (hands) to least clean area (elbows).

METHOD 2: ALCOHOL-BASED SURGICAL HAND RUB - Before applying alcohol-based surgical hand rub, prewash hands and forearms with plain (non-antimicrobial) soap and water. Dry hands and forearms completely with a disposable towel. Apply the manufacturer-recommended amount of alcohol-based surgical hand rub with persistent activity. Follow the manufacturer's instructions for application technique and duration. Allow hands and forearms to dry completely before donning sterile gloves.

ADVANTAGES OF ALCOHOL-BASED SURGICAL HAND RUB: Faster than traditional scrub (1.5-3 minutes vs. 2-6 minutes); more effective antimicrobial activity; better skin tolerance with less irritation and dryness; no need for water or sinks in the operating room; standardized application reduces variability in technique.

RINSING (FOR SOAP SCRUB): After scrubbing, rinse hands and forearms thoroughly, keeping hands elevated and elbows down. Allow water to flow from fingertips to elbows. Do not touch the faucet or sink after rinsing.

DRYING: Dry hands and forearms using a sterile towel, using a patting motion rather than rubbing. Dry one hand and arm completely before drying the other. Maintain hands above waist level and away from the body to avoid contamination.

DONNING STERILE GLOVES: After surgical hand antisepsis, don sterile gloves using proper technique. Double gloving is recommended for procedures with increased risk of blood exposure, as it provides an additional barrier and allows for glove change if the outer glove is punctured.

MAINTAINING ANTISEPSIS: Resident skin flora begins to regrow under gloves during surgery. Antimicrobial agents with persistent activity (chlorhexidine, alcohol-based products) continue to suppress bacterial growth for several hours. If gloves are punctured or torn during surgery, change gloves immediately. Surgical hand antisepsis does not need to be repeated if gloves are changed during the same procedure.
keyPoints: Remove all jewelry before starting
Clean under fingernails with nail cleaner
Two methods: antimicrobial soap scrub (2-6 min) OR alcohol-based surgical hand rub
Scrub all surfaces of hands and forearms up to elbows
Keep hands elevated above elbows during scrubbing/rinsing
Alcohol-based method is faster, more effective, and better for skin
Dry with sterile towel using patting motion
Double gloving recommended for high-risk procedures

pages.name: Common Mistakes & How to Avoid Them
content: Even with training, healthcare workers commonly make mistakes during hand hygiene that reduce its effectiveness. Understanding these mistakes and how to avoid them is essential for optimal infection prevention.

MISTAKE 1: INSUFFICIENT PRODUCT VOLUME - Using too little alcohol-based hand rub is one of the most common errors. If hands feel dry before 20 seconds, insufficient product was used. Solution: Apply a palmful (3-5 mL) of ABHS, which may require 2 pumps from most dispensers. Hands should remain wet for the entire 20-second application.

MISTAKE 2: INADEQUATE DURATION - Rushing through hand hygiene and not allowing adequate contact time reduces effectiveness. ABHS requires ~20 seconds until hands are dry; soap and water requires 15-20 seconds of scrubbing. Solution: Use a mental timer (count to 20, recite the alphabet) to ensure adequate duration.

MISTAKE 3: MISSING KEY AREAS - Studies using fluorescent markers consistently show that thumbs, fingertips, and areas between fingers are most frequently missed. Solution: Follow the WHO 6-step technique systematically, paying special attention to these commonly missed areas.

MISTAKE 4: RINSING ABHS WITH WATER - Some healthcare workers rinse their hands with water after applying ABHS, which dilutes the product and reduces effectiveness. Solution: Allow ABHS to dry completely on hands without rinsing or wiping. ABHS is designed to evaporate, leaving hands dry and clean.

MISTAKE 5: NOT ALLOWING ABHS TO DRY COMPLETELY - Donning gloves or touching surfaces before ABHS has completely dried reduces antimicrobial effectiveness and can cause skin irritation. Solution: Continue rubbing hands until they feel completely dry before proceeding with patient care or donning gloves.

MISTAKE 6: WEARING GLOVES AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR HAND HYGIENE - Gloves are not a substitute for hand hygiene. Gloves can have microscopic holes, can be torn during use, and hands can become contaminated during glove removal. Solution: Always perform hand hygiene before donning gloves and immediately after removing gloves.

MISTAKE 7: WEARING JEWELRY DURING HAND HYGIENE - Rings, watches, and bracelets harbor microorganisms and interfere with effective hand hygiene. Skin under rings has higher bacterial counts than skin on fingers without rings. Solution: Remove jewelry before hand hygiene, especially before surgical procedures. If rings cannot be removed, ensure thorough cleaning around and under rings.

MISTAKE 8: REFILLING OR TOPPING OFF SOAP/ABHS DISPENSERS - Adding soap or ABHS to partially empty dispensers can introduce bacterial contamination. Multiple outbreaks have been linked to contaminated soap dispensers. Solution: Never refill or top off dispensers. Use single-use cartridges or ensure dispensers are completely emptied, cleaned, and dried before refilling according to manufacturer instructions.

MISTAKE 9: USING ABHS ON VISIBLY SOILED HANDS - ABHS is not effective on hands with visible dirt, blood, or body fluids. Organic material interferes with antimicrobial activity. Solution: Always wash visibly soiled hands with soap and water before using ABHS.

MISTAKE 10: LONG OR ARTIFICIAL FINGERNAILS - Long natural nails (extending past fingertip) and artificial nails harbor more microorganisms and are difficult to clean effectively. Artificial nails have been implicated in multiple healthcare-associated infection outbreaks. Solution: Keep natural nails short (not extending past fingertip). Healthcare workers with direct patient contact, especially in high-risk areas (ICU, OR), should not wear artificial nails or extenders.

MISTAKE 11: INADEQUATE HAND DRYING AFTER HANDWASHING - Wet or damp hands transfer microorganisms more efficiently than dry hands. Incomplete drying reduces the effectiveness of handwashing. Solution: Dry hands thoroughly with disposable paper towels using a patting motion. Ensure hands are completely dry before proceeding with patient care.
keyPoints: Use adequate product volume (palmful, may need 2 pumps)
Allow adequate duration (20 sec for ABHS, 15-20 sec scrubbing for soap)
Pay attention to commonly missed areas (thumbs, fingertips, between fingers)
Never rinse ABHS with water - let it dry completely
Gloves are NOT a substitute for hand hygiene
Remove jewelry before hand hygiene
Never refill or top off soap/ABHS dispensers
Wash visibly soiled hands with soap and water, not ABHS
Keep nails short; no artificial nails for direct patient contact
Dry hands completely after handwashing

sections.name: Compliance Monitoring
sections.description: Methods and strategies for monitoring and improving hand hygiene compliance

pages.name: Direct Observation Method
content: Direct observation by trained observers is considered the gold standard for measuring hand hygiene compliance. This method involves human observers watching healthcare workers during patient care and recording whether hand hygiene is performed at appropriate moments.

ADVANTAGES OF DIRECT OBSERVATION: Provides real-time data on actual hand hygiene behavior; allows assessment of technique quality, not just whether hand hygiene occurred; can identify specific moments where compliance is low; provides opportunity for immediate feedback and education; considered most accurate method for compliance measurement.

OBSERVER TRAINING: Observers must be thoroughly trained to recognize the WHO 5 Moments for Hand Hygiene and to use standardized observation tools. Training should include: understanding of hand hygiene indications; recognition of hand hygiene opportunities; proper use of observation forms; maintaining objectivity and consistency; avoiding disruption of patient care.

OBSERVATION FREQUENCY: Most guidelines recommend 10-30 observations per unit per month as a minimum. More frequent observations provide more reliable data but require more resources. Observations should be distributed across different times of day, days of week, and types of patient care activities to obtain representative data.

OBSERVATION DURATION: Each observation session typically lasts 15-30 minutes. Observers should position themselves to clearly see hand hygiene opportunities without interfering with patient care. Multiple healthcare workers may be observed during a single session.

HAWTHORNE EFFECT: Healthcare workers tend to improve their behavior when they know they are being observed. This 'Hawthorne effect' can artificially inflate compliance rates. Strategies to minimize this effect include: using covert observation when ethically appropriate; conducting frequent observations so staff become accustomed to being observed; using electronic monitoring systems; emphasizing that observations are for quality improvement, not individual performance evaluation.

OBSERVER POSITIONING: Observers should position themselves where they can clearly see hand hygiene opportunities and actions without interfering with patient care. In patient rooms, observers typically stand near the door or in a corner. Observers should avoid making eye contact with healthcare workers being observed to minimize the Hawthorne effect.

WHAT TO RECORD: For each hand hygiene opportunity, record: the moment (1-5); whether hand hygiene was performed (yes/no); the method used (ABHS or soap and water); the healthcare worker category (nurse, physician, respiratory therapist, etc.); the location (ICU, medical ward, etc.); any relevant contextual factors.

CALCULATING COMPLIANCE: Hand hygiene compliance is calculated as: (Number of hand hygiene actions performed / Number of hand hygiene opportunities) × 100%. Compliance can be calculated overall, by moment, by healthcare worker category, by unit, or by other relevant categories.

INTER-RATER RELIABILITY: When multiple observers are used, it is important to assess inter-rater reliability to ensure consistency. Observers should periodically observe the same situations and compare results. Discrepancies should be discussed and resolved through additional training.

FEEDBACK TO STAFF: Observation data should be shared with healthcare workers regularly. Feedback should be timely (within days or weeks of observation), specific (by unit, by moment), non-punitive, and focused on improvement opportunities. Positive feedback for high compliance is as important as identifying areas for improvement.
keyPoints: Gold standard for hand hygiene compliance measurement
Requires trained observers using standardized tools
Recommend 10-30 observations per unit per month minimum
Hawthorne effect: compliance increases when observed
Record moment, action performed, method, healthcare worker category
Compliance = (actions performed / opportunities) × 100%
Provide timely, specific, non-punitive feedback to staff

pages.name: WHO Hand Hygiene Observation Tool
content: The WHO Hand Hygiene Observation Form is a standardized tool used worldwide for monitoring hand hygiene compliance. It is designed to be simple, practical, and applicable across diverse healthcare settings.

TOOL STRUCTURE: The WHO observation form includes fields for: facility information (name, ward, date); observer information; session details (start/end time, duration); individual observations with columns for each of the 5 moments; healthcare worker category; hand hygiene action (performed or missed); method used (ABHS or soap and water).

HOW TO USE THE TOOL: Step 1 - Complete header information (facility, ward, date, observer name, session start time). Step 2 - Observe healthcare workers during patient care activities. Step 3 - For each hand hygiene opportunity, mark the appropriate moment (1-5) and whether hand hygiene was performed. Step 4 - Record the healthcare worker category and method used. Step 5 - At the end of the session, complete the session end time and calculate totals.

RECORDING OBSERVATIONS: Each row on the form represents one hand hygiene opportunity. Mark the moment column (1-5) where the opportunity occurred. In the 'Action' column, mark whether hand hygiene was performed (✓) or missed (X). If performed, indicate the method (HR for hand rub/ABHS, HW for handwashing with soap and water). Record the healthcare worker category using standard abbreviations (N for nurse, D for doctor, etc.).

MULTIPLE OPPORTUNITIES IN ONE ENCOUNTER: Healthcare workers often have multiple hand hygiene opportunities during a single patient encounter. Each opportunity should be recorded as a separate observation. For example, a nurse entering a patient room (Moment 1), performing wound care (Moment 2), and leaving the room (Moment 4) would generate three separate observations.

CALCULATING COMPLIANCE RATES: After completing observations, calculate compliance rates using the totals section of the form. Overall compliance = (Total actions performed / Total opportunities) × 100%. Compliance by moment = (Actions performed for that moment / Opportunities for that moment) × 100%. Compliance by healthcare worker category = (Actions performed by that category / Opportunities for that category) × 100%.

INTERPRETING RESULTS: Compliance rates should be interpreted in context. Rates below 50% indicate significant improvement opportunities. Rates of 50-70% suggest moderate compliance with room for improvement. Rates above 70% indicate good compliance, though the goal should be >90%. Examine compliance by moment to identify specific opportunities for targeted interventions.

COMMON PATTERNS: Typical patterns observed include: Moment 1 (before touching patient) often has lower compliance than Moment 4 (after touching patient); Moment 2 (before aseptic procedure) typically has higher compliance due to perceived risk; Moment 5 (after touching patient surroundings) often has the lowest compliance; Physicians typically have lower compliance than nurses; Compliance is often lower during busy periods or emergencies.

DATA ENTRY AND ANALYSIS: Observation data should be entered into a database or spreadsheet for analysis and trending over time. Many facilities use electronic data capture tools or mobile apps to streamline data entry. Data should be analyzed regularly (monthly or quarterly) to identify trends and evaluate the impact of improvement interventions.

REPORTING RESULTS: Compliance data should be reported to healthcare workers, unit leadership, and facility infection prevention committees. Reports should include: overall compliance rate; compliance by moment; compliance by healthcare worker category; trends over time; comparison to previous periods or benchmarks; specific improvement opportunities identified.

LIMITATIONS OF THE TOOL: The WHO observation tool has some limitations: subject to Hawthorne effect; labor-intensive and requires dedicated observer time; may not capture all hand hygiene opportunities in fast-paced environments; does not assess technique quality; provides snapshot data rather than continuous monitoring. Despite these limitations, it remains the most widely used and validated tool for hand hygiene compliance measurement.

Each hand hygiene opportunity is recorded as separate observation

Report results regularly with trends and improvement opportunities
Limitations: Hawthorne effect, labor-intensive, snapshot data

pages.name: Audit and Feedback Strategies
content: Audit and feedback is a quality improvement strategy that involves measuring hand hygiene compliance, analyzing the data, and providing feedback to healthcare workers. When implemented effectively, audit and feedback can significantly improve hand hygiene compliance.

ESTABLISHING BASELINE: Before implementing improvement interventions, establish a baseline compliance rate through direct observation. Baseline data should be collected over several weeks to ensure reliability. Baseline data provides a reference point for measuring improvement and helps identify specific areas needing intervention.

SETTING IMPROVEMENT GOALS: Based on baseline data, set realistic, measurable improvement goals. Goals should be specific (e.g., 'increase overall compliance from 45% to 60% within 6 months'), time-bound, and achievable. Consider setting different goals for different moments or healthcare worker categories based on baseline performance.

FREQUENCY OF AUDITS: Regular, ongoing audits are more effective than one-time measurements. Most successful programs conduct audits monthly or quarterly. More frequent audits (weekly or biweekly) may be appropriate during intensive improvement campaigns or in high-risk units.

TYPES OF FEEDBACK: Feedback can be provided at multiple levels: Individual feedback - direct, immediate feedback to individual healthcare workers during or after observation; Unit-level feedback - aggregate data shared with all staff on a unit through posters, newsletters, or staff meetings; Facility-level feedback - organization-wide data shared through quality dashboards, committee reports, or facility newsletters.

TIMING OF FEEDBACK: Feedback is most effective when provided promptly. Individual feedback should be immediate or within hours. Unit-level feedback should be provided within days or weeks of data collection. Delayed feedback (months after observation) has minimal impact on behavior change.

CONTENT OF FEEDBACK: Effective feedback includes: current compliance rate; comparison to previous periods (trend data); comparison to goals or benchmarks; specific moments or situations where compliance is low; recognition of improvements and high performers; specific action plans for improvement.

POSITIVE VS. CORRECTIVE FEEDBACK: Both positive and corrective feedback are important. Positive feedback (recognizing high compliance or improvement) reinforces desired behavior and maintains motivation. Corrective feedback (identifying low compliance areas) guides improvement efforts. The ratio should favor positive feedback to avoid creating a punitive atmosphere.

VISUAL DISPLAYS: Visual displays of compliance data are highly effective. Examples include: run charts or line graphs showing compliance trends over time; bar charts comparing compliance by moment or healthcare worker category; thermometer-style displays showing progress toward goals; traffic light systems (red/yellow/green) indicating performance levels.

PEER COMPARISON: Providing comparative data (e.g., 'Your unit's compliance is 65%, while the facility average is 58%') can motivate improvement. However, comparisons should be used carefully to avoid creating competition that undermines collaboration. Focus on improvement rather than ranking.

LINKING FEEDBACK TO OUTCOMES: When possible, link hand hygiene compliance data to infection rates. For example, 'Our unit's CLABSI rate decreased from 3.2 to 1.5 per 1,000 line-days after improving hand hygiene compliance from 50% to 75%.' This demonstrates the real-world impact of hand hygiene and reinforces its importance.

PDSA CYCLES: Use Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycles for continuous improvement. Plan: Identify a specific improvement opportunity and plan an intervention. Do: Implement the intervention on a small scale. Study: Measure compliance and evaluate the intervention's effectiveness. Act: If successful, spread the intervention more widely; if not, modify and try again.

SUSTAINING IMPROVEMENT: Maintaining high compliance over time requires ongoing effort. Strategies for sustainability include: continuing regular audits and feedback; integrating hand hygiene into organizational culture and values; maintaining leadership support and accountability; refreshing education and reminders periodically; celebrating successes and recognizing high performers.

pages.name: Product Usage Monitoring
content: Product usage monitoring involves tracking the consumption of alcohol-based hand sanitizer (ABHS) and soap to estimate hand hygiene activity. This method provides an indirect measure of hand hygiene compliance and is useful as a supplement to direct observation.

HOW IT WORKS: Facilities track the volume of ABHS and soap used over a defined period (typically monthly) and calculate usage per patient-day or per 1,000 patient-days. Higher usage suggests more frequent hand hygiene, while lower usage may indicate compliance problems.

CALCULATING USAGE RATE: ABHS usage rate = (Total mL of ABHS used / Total patient-days) × 1,000. For example, if a unit used 50,000 mL of ABHS in a month with 800 patient-days, the usage rate would be (50,000 / 800) × 1,000 = 62,500 mL per 1,000 patient-days, or 62.5 mL per patient-day.

BENCHMARKS: There is no universally accepted benchmark for ABHS usage, as appropriate usage varies by patient acuity, type of care, and hand hygiene opportunities. However, some studies suggest: General medical-surgical units: 10-30 mL per patient-day; Intensive care units: 30-100 mL per patient-day; Emergency departments: 20-50 mL per patient-day. These are rough guidelines; facilities should establish their own benchmarks based on direct observation data.

ADVANTAGES OF PRODUCT USAGE MONITORING: Easy to implement and requires minimal resources; provides continuous data rather than snapshots; not subject to Hawthorne effect; can track trends over time; useful for identifying units with very low usage that may need intervention; can be automated through inventory management systems.

LIMITATIONS: Does not measure actual compliance (only product consumption); cannot identify which moments have low compliance; does not assess technique quality; can be affected by product waste, theft, or evaporation; does not account for differences in hand hygiene opportunities across units; cannot distinguish between appropriate and inappropriate hand hygiene.

INTERPRETING USAGE DATA: Increasing usage over time generally indicates improving hand hygiene activity, but should be correlated with direct observation data to confirm actual compliance improvement. Sudden decreases in usage may indicate supply problems, dispenser malfunctions, or declining compliance. Large variations between similar units may indicate compliance differences or differences in patient acuity.

COMBINING WITH DIRECT OBSERVATION: Product usage monitoring is most useful when combined with direct observation. For example, if direct observation shows 60% compliance and ABHS usage is low, this confirms a compliance problem. If direct observation shows 80% compliance but ABHS usage is low, this may indicate technique problems (insufficient product volume) or reliance on handwashing instead of ABHS.

TRACKING METHODS: Manual tracking: Count bottles or cartridges used each month and multiply by volume per container. Automated tracking: Some dispenser systems have electronic counters that track each dispenser activation. Inventory management: Track ABHS orders and deliveries to estimate usage. Weighing: Weigh ABHS containers before and after use to calculate consumption.

REPORTING USAGE DATA: Report ABHS usage rates monthly or quarterly alongside direct observation compliance data. Display trends over time using line graphs. Compare usage across units to identify outliers. Investigate sudden changes in usage patterns. Use usage data to identify units that may benefit from targeted observation and intervention.

PRODUCT WASTE CONSIDERATIONS: Be aware that not all product consumption represents actual hand hygiene. Sources of waste include: product evaporation from open containers; accidental dispenser activation; product spills; theft or diversion for non-healthcare use. Minimize waste by using sealed cartridge systems, maintaining dispensers properly, and educating staff about appropriate use.

pages.name: Improving Compliance Rates
content: Improving hand hygiene compliance requires a comprehensive, multimodal approach that addresses multiple barriers and uses multiple strategies simultaneously. The WHO Multimodal Hand Hygiene Improvement Strategy provides a framework for systematic improvement.

WHO MULTIMODAL STRATEGY COMPONENTS: The WHO strategy includes five components that should be implemented together: 1) System change (ensuring ABHS is available at point of care); 2) Education and training; 3) Observation and feedback; 4) Reminders in the workplace; 5) Institutional safety climate (leadership support, accountability).

SYSTEM CHANGE - PRODUCT AVAILABILITY: Ensure ABHS is available at every point of care, including: bedside (wall-mounted or portable dispensers); room entrances; nursing stations; medication preparation areas; procedure rooms. Studies show that improving ABHS accessibility can increase compliance by 20-30%. The goal is to make hand hygiene easier to perform than to skip.

EDUCATION AND TRAINING: Provide initial and ongoing education to all healthcare workers on: WHO 5 Moments for Hand Hygiene; proper hand hygiene technique; rationale for hand hygiene (link to infection prevention); local compliance data and improvement goals. Education should be interactive, practical, and repeated regularly (annually at minimum). New staff should receive hand hygiene education during orientation.

OBSERVATION AND FEEDBACK: Implement regular direct observation with timely feedback as described in previous sections. Observation and feedback is one of the most effective strategies for improving compliance. Ensure feedback is non-punitive, specific, and focused on improvement opportunities.

REMINDERS IN THE WORKPLACE: Use visual reminders to prompt hand hygiene at critical moments: WHO 5 Moments posters at room entrances and nursing stations; stickers or decals near dispensers; screen savers on computers; badge cards for healthcare workers; patient education materials encouraging patients to remind staff. Reminders should be refreshed periodically to maintain visibility and impact.

INSTITUTIONAL SAFETY CLIMATE: Create an organizational culture that prioritizes hand hygiene: Leadership commitment - senior leaders visibly support hand hygiene and participate in campaigns; Accountability - include hand hygiene in performance evaluations and quality metrics; Resources - allocate budget for ABHS, dispensers, education, and monitoring; Recognition - celebrate successes and recognize high-performing units or individuals; Patient involvement - encourage patients to ask healthcare workers if they have cleaned their hands.

ADDRESSING SPECIFIC BARRIERS: Identify and address barriers to hand hygiene in your facility: Time constraints - improve workflow efficiency, ensure adequate staffing; Skin irritation - provide high-quality ABHS and hand lotion, educate on proper technique; Forgetfulness - increase reminders, improve product accessibility; Lack of knowledge - provide education and training; Low perceived risk - share local infection data, emphasize patient safety; Lack of role models - engage champions and opinion leaders.

CHAMPIONS AND OPINION LEADERS: Identify and engage hand hygiene champions on each unit. Champions should be respected, influential healthcare workers who model excellent hand hygiene and encourage peers. Champions can: conduct peer observations and provide feedback; lead unit-based improvement initiatives; share success stories; mentor new staff; maintain enthusiasm and momentum.

PATIENT ENGAGEMENT: Empower patients and families to participate in hand hygiene improvement: Provide patient education materials about hand hygiene importance; Encourage patients to ask healthcare workers 'Have you cleaned your hands?'; Display hand hygiene compliance data in patient areas; Include hand hygiene in patient satisfaction surveys; Recognize that patient reminders can be uncomfortable for some healthcare workers; frame patient involvement as partnership for safety.

TECHNOLOGY SOLUTIONS: Consider electronic hand hygiene monitoring systems that use sensors to detect hand hygiene events and provide real-time feedback. These systems can: reduce Hawthorne effect; provide continuous monitoring rather than snapshots; give immediate feedback to healthcare workers; generate detailed compliance reports. However, these systems are expensive and may have technical limitations.

SUSTAINING HIGH COMPLIANCE: Maintaining high compliance over time is challenging. Strategies for sustainability include: continue regular monitoring and feedback; refresh education and reminders periodically; maintain leadership support and accountability; integrate hand hygiene into organizational culture; celebrate ongoing successes; address new barriers as they emerge; share best practices across units.

MEASURING SUCCESS: Track multiple metrics to evaluate improvement efforts: hand hygiene compliance rates (overall and by moment); ABHS usage per patient-day; healthcare-associated infection rates; healthcare worker knowledge and attitudes (surveys); patient satisfaction with hand hygiene. Improvement in compliance should ultimately lead to reduction in infection rates, though this may take time to demonstrate.

pages.name: ABHS Dispenser Placement & Requirements
content: Proper placement and accessibility of alcohol-based hand sanitizer (ABHS) dispensers is critical for hand hygiene compliance. Studies consistently show that improving ABHS accessibility increases compliance by 20-30%.

POINT-OF-CARE PLACEMENT: ABHS should be available at every point of care, defined as the place where three elements come together: the patient, the healthcare worker, and care or treatment involving contact with the patient or their surroundings. This typically includes: immediately outside or inside patient room entrances; at the patient's bedside (wall-mounted or portable); at nursing stations; in medication preparation areas; in procedure rooms; at mobile workstations or computers on wheels.

ROOM ENTRANCE DISPENSERS: Place dispensers immediately outside or just inside patient room entrances at a height of 42-48 inches (107-122 cm) from the floor for optimal accessibility. Dispensers should be visible and easily accessible without requiring healthcare workers to search or reach awkwardly. Consider placing dispensers on both sides of doorways in high-traffic areas.

BEDSIDE DISPENSERS: Bedside dispensers ensure ABHS is available during patient care without requiring healthcare workers to leave the patient zone. Options include: wall-mounted dispensers on the wall behind the patient's bed; portable dispensers attached to bed rails or IV poles; individual pocket-sized bottles carried by healthcare workers. Wall-mounted bedside dispensers are preferred as they are always available and reduce the risk of running out.

DISPENSER DENSITY: Guidelines recommend a minimum of one ABHS dispenser per patient room, with additional dispensers in common areas. High-performing facilities often exceed this minimum, with 2-3 dispensers per patient room (entrance, bedside, and bathroom area). ICUs and other high-acuity areas may require even higher dispenser density due to frequent hand hygiene opportunities.

DISPENSER VISIBILITY: Dispensers should be highly visible and easily identifiable. Strategies to improve visibility include: bright colors or signage; consistent placement across all rooms; adequate lighting; clear sightlines without obstructions; WHO 5 Moments posters or reminders near dispensers.

DISPENSER TYPES: Common dispenser types include: wall-mounted dispensers (most common, reliable, always available); portable dispensers (flexible placement, can be moved to point of care); individual pocket bottles (convenient but risk of running out, contamination); touchless/automatic dispensers (reduce cross-contamination, may improve compliance). Wall-mounted dispensers with manual pumps are most cost-effective and reliable.

DISPENSER MAINTENANCE: Regular maintenance is essential to ensure dispensers are always functional and filled: check and refill dispensers daily or more frequently in high-use areas; clean dispensers regularly to prevent buildup; repair or replace malfunctioning dispensers immediately; never refill or top off dispensers (use sealed cartridges); monitor for leaks, clogs, or mechanical problems.

DISPENSER CAPACITY: Choose dispensers with adequate capacity for the usage rate of the area. High-traffic areas may require larger capacity dispensers (1000-1200 mL) to reduce refilling frequency. Smaller capacity dispensers (500-800 mL) may be appropriate for lower-traffic areas. Consider usage data when selecting dispenser capacity.

ACCESSIBILITY CONSIDERATIONS: Ensure dispensers are accessible to all healthcare workers, including those with disabilities. Consider: height appropriate for wheelchair users (34-48 inches from floor); easy-to-operate pumps that don't require excessive force; clear space in front of dispensers for wheelchair access; tactile or audible indicators for visually impaired users.

FIRE SAFETY COMPLIANCE: ABHS dispensers must comply with fire safety codes (NFPA 101 Life Safety Code). Key requirements include: maximum 95% alcohol concentration; maximum 1.2 L (41 oz) dispenser capacity in corridors; minimum 1 inch (2.5 cm) separation from ignition sources; maximum total ABHS volume per floor area; dispensers in smoke compartments. See the Fire Safety page for detailed requirements.

pages.name: Sink and Soap Dispenser Requirements
content: While ABHS is the preferred method for hand hygiene in most situations, handwashing sinks and soap dispensers remain essential infrastructure. Proper design, placement, and maintenance of sinks and soap dispensers are critical for effective hand hygiene.

SINK PLACEMENT: Sinks should be conveniently located in areas where handwashing is required: patient room bathrooms; dedicated handwashing sinks in patient rooms (in addition to bathroom sinks); soiled utility rooms; medication preparation areas; food preparation areas; staff break rooms and restrooms. Sinks should be easily accessible without requiring healthcare workers to leave the patient care area when handwashing is needed.

SINK DESIGN: Handwashing sinks should be designed to minimize splash and contamination: deep basin to contain splashing; hands-free or foot-operated faucets preferred (reduce recontamination); adequate clearance around sink for comfortable use; separate sinks for handwashing vs. clinical procedures (don't use clinical sinks for handwashing); avoid sinks with overflow drains (can harbor bacteria).

HANDS-FREE FAUCETS: Hands-free faucets (automatic sensors, foot pedals, or elbow/knee controls) are strongly preferred for handwashing sinks to prevent recontamination of clean hands when turning off the faucet. If manual faucets are present, provide paper towels so healthcare workers can use a towel to turn off the faucet after handwashing.

WATER TEMPERATURE: Provide warm or cold water for handwashing. Hot water is not necessary for effective handwashing and increases the risk of skin irritation and burns. Water temperature should be comfortable (60-105°F or 15-40°C). Avoid excessively hot water that can damage skin and reduce hand hygiene compliance.

SOAP DISPENSER TYPES: Common soap dispenser types include: sealed cartridge systems (preferred, reduce contamination risk); bulk refillable dispensers (higher contamination risk, not recommended); bar soap (not recommended in healthcare settings due to contamination risk); foam soap dispensers (use less product, may be more acceptable to users).

SOAP DISPENSER PLACEMENT: Place soap dispensers within easy reach of the sink, typically on the wall above or beside the sink. Dispensers should be positioned so users don't have to reach over the sink (causing drips) or turn away from the sink. Ensure adequate clearance for easy operation.

SOAP SELECTION: Plain (non-antimicrobial) soap is adequate for routine handwashing in most healthcare settings. Antimicrobial soap containing chlorhexidine, triclosan, or other antiseptic agents may be used in specific situations (surgical hand antisepsis, outbreak settings) but offers no additional benefit for routine handwashing and may contribute to antimicrobial resistance. Choose soap products that are: effective at removing dirt and microorganisms; well-tolerated by users (low irritation); compatible with ABHS products used in the facility; cost-effective.

DISPENSER MAINTENANCE AND REFILLING: Proper dispenser maintenance is critical to prevent contamination: NEVER refill or top off soap dispensers (multiple outbreaks linked to contaminated soap); use sealed, single-use cartridges whenever possible; if bulk refillable dispensers must be used, completely empty, clean, and dry dispensers before refilling; clean exterior of dispensers regularly; monitor for clogs, leaks, or malfunctions and repair immediately.

CONTAMINATED SOAP OUTBREAKS: Multiple healthcare-associated infection outbreaks have been linked to contaminated soap in refillable dispensers. Bacteria (especially Gram-negative organisms like Pseudomonas, Serratia, and Burkholderia) can grow in soap, especially when dispensers are topped off rather than completely emptied and cleaned. Contaminated soap can actually increase bacterial counts on hands after washing.

PAPER TOWEL DISPENSERS: Provide paper towel dispensers at every handwashing sink. Cloth towels are not appropriate in healthcare settings due to contamination risk. Paper towel dispensers should be: hands-free (automatic or lever-operated) to prevent recontamination; positioned within easy reach of the sink; regularly refilled to ensure availability; designed to dispense one towel at a time to reduce waste.

SINK MAINTENANCE: Regular maintenance of handwashing sinks is essential: clean and disinfect sinks daily or more frequently if visibly soiled; ensure drains are clear and functioning properly; repair leaks promptly; ensure adequate water pressure and temperature; monitor for biofilm buildup in drains and faucets; consider periodic drain disinfection in high-risk areas.

pages.name: Product Selection Criteria
content: Selecting appropriate hand hygiene products is critical for compliance and effectiveness. Products should be effective at killing microorganisms, well-tolerated by users, cost-effective, and compatible with other products used in the facility.

ABHS ALCOHOL CONCENTRATION: ABHS products should contain 60-95% alcohol (ethanol or isopropanol). Products with <60% alcohol have reduced antimicrobial efficacy. Products with >95% alcohol are less effective because proteins are not denatured as effectively in the absence of water. The optimal concentration is 70-80% alcohol.

ALCOHOL TYPE: Both ethanol and isopropanol are effective for ABHS. Ethanol is more commonly used and may have slightly better antimicrobial activity against some viruses. Isopropanol may be less drying to skin. Some products contain a combination of both alcohols. Choose based on availability, cost, and user preference.

FORMULATION: ABHS products are available in gel, foam, and liquid formulations. Gels are most common and preferred by many users. Foams use less product per application and may be more cost-effective. Liquids dry faster but may drip. Choose formulation based on user preference, cost, and dispenser compatibility.

EMOLLIENTS AND SKIN CONDITIONERS: ABHS products should contain emollients (moisturizers) to minimize skin dryness and irritation. Common emollients include glycerin, propylene glycol, and various oils. Products with emollients improve skin tolerance and compliance. Evaluate products for skin tolerance through user trials before facility-wide implementation.

FRAGRANCE: Fragrance-free or low-fragrance products are preferred, especially for healthcare workers with sensitivities or allergies. Strong fragrances can cause headaches, nausea, or allergic reactions in some users. If fragranced products are used, choose mild, pleasant scents that are well-tolerated by most users.

ANTIMICROBIAL EFFICACY TESTING: ABHS products should meet recognized standards for antimicrobial efficacy, such as: ASTM E1174 (test method for evaluation of hand hygiene products); EN 1500 (European standard for hygienic hand disinfection); FDA Tentative Final Monograph for Healthcare Antiseptic Products. Request efficacy data from manufacturers before product selection.

SOAP PRODUCT SELECTION: For handwashing soap, consider: plain soap is adequate for routine handwashing; antimicrobial soap for surgical hand antisepsis or specific outbreak situations; low irritation and good skin tolerance; pleasant scent and texture (improves user acceptance); compatibility with ABHS products (some combinations can cause skin irritation); cost-effectiveness.

USER ACCEPTANCE: User acceptance is critical for compliance. Involve healthcare workers in product selection through: user trials with multiple products; surveys or focus groups to gather feedback; evaluation of skin tolerance, scent, texture, and ease of use; consideration of user preferences when making final selection. Products that are disliked by users will have lower compliance regardless of efficacy.

COST CONSIDERATIONS: Evaluate total cost of ownership, not just product cost: product cost per mL or per application; dispenser cost and maintenance; waste and spillage; impact on compliance (more expensive products may improve compliance, reducing infection costs); volume discounts for large purchases; contract terms and pricing stability.

COMPATIBILITY: Ensure hand hygiene products are compatible with: gloves used in the facility (some ABHS products can degrade certain glove materials); other skin care products (lotions, barrier creams); dispensers (viscosity, cartridge design); facility infrastructure (no damage to surfaces or finishes).

SUPPLY CHAIN RELIABILITY: Choose products from manufacturers with reliable supply chains. Consider: manufacturer reputation and stability; availability of products during shortages (e.g., COVID-19 pandemic); lead times for orders; ability to provide alternative products if primary product unavailable; local vs. national suppliers.

PRODUCT EVALUATION PROCESS: Establish a systematic process for evaluating and selecting hand hygiene products: form a multidisciplinary selection committee (infection prevention, nursing, purchasing, facilities); define evaluation criteria (efficacy, skin tolerance, user acceptance, cost); conduct user trials with 2-3 finalist products; gather feedback through surveys; analyze cost and supply chain factors; make final selection based on comprehensive evaluation; plan for implementation and education.

pages.name: Fire Safety (NFPA 101 Compliance)
content: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer (ABHS) is flammable and must be installed and used in compliance with fire safety codes. The National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 101 Life Safety Code provides specific requirements for ABHS dispensers in healthcare facilities.

ALCOHOL CONCENTRATION LIMIT: ABHS dispensers in healthcare facilities must contain products with a maximum of 95% alcohol by volume. Products with >95% alcohol are not permitted. Most ABHS products contain 60-80% alcohol and are well within this limit.

DISPENSER CAPACITY LIMITS: In corridors and areas open to corridors, individual ABHS dispensers are limited to a maximum capacity of 1.2 liters (41 ounces) of ABHS. Larger capacity dispensers (up to 2 liters) may be used in rooms or suites separated from corridors by doors. These limits are designed to limit the fuel load in case of fire.

SEPARATION FROM IGNITION SOURCES: ABHS dispensers must be separated from electrical receptacles, switches, and other ignition sources by at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) horizontally. This separation reduces the risk of ignition from electrical sparks. Dispensers should not be installed directly above or adjacent to electrical outlets.

DISPENSER SPACING: Where multiple ABHS dispensers are installed in the same corridor, they must be separated by at least 48 inches (122 cm). This spacing requirement limits the total fuel load in any given area and reduces the risk of fire spread between dispensers.

MAXIMUM ABHS VOLUME PER FLOOR: The total volume of ABHS in dispensers is limited based on the floor area and presence of sprinkler systems. In sprinklered smoke compartments, the maximum is 10 gallons (37.8 liters) per 1,000 square feet of floor area. In non-sprinklered areas, the limit is 5 gallons (18.9 liters) per 1,000 square feet. Most healthcare facilities are fully sprinklered and can accommodate the higher limit.

SMOKE COMPARTMENTS: ABHS dispensers must be located within smoke compartments. Smoke compartments are areas separated by smoke barriers (walls and doors) that limit smoke spread in case of fire. Healthcare facilities are typically divided into smoke compartments of 22,500 square feet or less. ABHS volume limits apply per smoke compartment.

DISPENSER INSTALLATION: ABHS dispensers must be installed in accordance with manufacturer instructions and fire safety codes. Key installation requirements include: secure mounting to wall or other fixed structure; proper height for accessibility (typically 42-48 inches from floor); adequate clearance from ignition sources; compliance with capacity and spacing limits; installation by qualified personnel.

STORAGE OF ABHS: Bulk storage of ABHS (containers larger than dispensers) must comply with flammable liquid storage requirements. Large quantities of ABHS should be stored in approved flammable liquid storage cabinets or rooms. Storage areas should be well-ventilated, away from ignition sources, and clearly labeled. Limit the quantity of ABHS stored in patient care areas.

FIRE RISK ASSESSMENT: While ABHS is flammable, the actual fire risk in healthcare facilities is very low when products are used as intended. Studies and fire incident data show that ABHS-related fires are extremely rare. The infection prevention benefits of ABHS far outweigh the minimal fire risk. However, compliance with fire safety codes is essential to minimize risk.

EDUCATION ON FIRE SAFETY: Educate healthcare workers on safe use of ABHS: use ABHS as directed (apply to hands and rub until dry); do not use ABHS near open flames or heat sources; do not store ABHS in hot environments (e.g., cars in summer); report any ABHS spills immediately for cleanup; report malfunctioning dispensers that leak or drip; follow facility fire safety policies and procedures.

COORDINATION WITH FIRE SAFETY OFFICIALS: Work closely with facility fire safety officials and local fire marshals when planning ABHS dispenser installation. Provide documentation of NFPA 101 compliance. Conduct fire safety inspections to verify compliance with dispenser capacity, spacing, and separation requirements. Update fire safety plans to include ABHS dispenser locations and volumes.

pages.name: Hand Hygiene for C. difficile
content: Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile) is a spore-forming bacterium that causes healthcare-associated diarrhea. Hand hygiene for C. difficile requires special considerations because alcohol-based hand sanitizer (ABHS) does not kill C. difficile spores.

WHY ABHS IS NOT EFFECTIVE AGAINST SPORES: ABHS is highly effective against vegetative bacteria, viruses, and fungi, but it does not kill bacterial spores. C. difficile produces spores that are resistant to alcohol and many disinfectants. Spores can survive on hands and environmental surfaces for extended periods and can be transmitted to patients if hand hygiene is inadequate.

SOAP AND WATER FOR C. DIFFICILE: Handwashing with soap and water is more effective than ABHS for removing C. difficile spores from hands. Soap and water physically removes spores through mechanical action and rinsing, even though it does not kill them. The friction of handwashing and the flow of water wash spores down the drain.

CURRENT CDC RECOMMENDATIONS: The CDC recommends the following hand hygiene practices for C. difficile: Use ABHS for routine hand hygiene in all situations EXCEPT when caring for patients with C. difficile infection during outbreaks. During C. difficile outbreaks, use soap and water preferentially for hand hygiene after caring for patients with C. difficile infection. Glove use is critical when caring for patients with C. difficile infection.

RATIONALE FOR CONTINUED ABHS USE: Despite ABHS not killing spores, the CDC continues to recommend ABHS for routine hand hygiene (even in endemic C. difficile situations) because: ABHS is more effective than soap and water against most other pathogens; ABHS compliance is typically higher than handwashing compliance; the overall infection prevention benefit of ABHS outweighs the C. difficile spore concern; proper glove use is the primary barrier against C. difficile transmission.

WHEN TO USE SOAP AND WATER: Use soap and water instead of ABHS in the following situations: After caring for patients with known or suspected C. difficile infection during outbreaks; When hands are visibly soiled with feces; After removing gloves following care of patients with C. difficile infection during outbreaks. During endemic (non-outbreak) C. difficile situations, ABHS remains acceptable for routine hand hygiene.

IMPORTANCE OF GLOVE USE: Gloves are the primary barrier against C. difficile transmission. Always wear gloves when caring for patients with C. difficile infection, especially when contact with feces or contaminated surfaces is likely. Remove gloves promptly after use and perform hand hygiene immediately. Gloves should be changed between tasks on the same patient if moving from contaminated to clean body sites.

HANDWASHING TECHNIQUE FOR C. DIFFICILE: When handwashing for C. difficile, use proper technique: wet hands with water; apply soap; scrub vigorously for at least 20 seconds, paying attention to all hand surfaces; rinse thoroughly under running water; dry completely with disposable paper towel; use towel to turn off faucet. Vigorous scrubbing and thorough rinsing are critical for spore removal.

ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING: Hand hygiene alone is not sufficient to control C. difficile. Environmental cleaning with sporicidal disinfectants (bleach-based products) is essential. C. difficile spores can contaminate surfaces and be transferred to hands. Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces in rooms of patients with C. difficile infection daily and after discharge using EPA-registered sporicidal disinfectants.

CONTACT PRECAUTIONS: Patients with C. difficile infection should be placed on Contact Precautions, which include: single room (preferred) or cohorting with other C. difficile patients; glove and gown use for all patient contact; dedicated patient care equipment when possible; enhanced environmental cleaning with sporicidal disinfectants. Contact Precautions should continue until diarrhea resolves (typically 48 hours after last unformed stool).

OUTBREAK RESPONSE: During C. difficile outbreaks, implement enhanced hand hygiene measures: preferentially use soap and water instead of ABHS after caring for patients with C. difficile; increase hand hygiene monitoring and feedback; reinforce glove use and Contact Precautions; enhance environmental cleaning; review antibiotic stewardship practices; consider patient cohorting and staff cohorting.

EDUCATION: Educate healthcare workers on C. difficile transmission and prevention: ABHS does not kill spores; soap and water physically removes spores; gloves are the primary barrier; proper glove removal technique is critical; hand hygiene immediately after glove removal; environmental contamination is common; importance of Contact Precautions and environmental cleaning.

CDC recommends ABHS for routine hand hygiene except during C. difficile outbreaks
During outbreaks, use soap and water after caring for C. difficile patients
Glove use is the primary barrier against C. difficile transmission
Handwashing technique: vigorous scrubbing for 20+ seconds, thorough rinsing
Environmental cleaning with sporicidal disinfectants (bleach) essential
Contact Precautions required for C. difficile patients

pages.name: Glove Use & Hand Hygiene
content: Gloves are an important component of infection prevention, but they are not a substitute for hand hygiene. Understanding the relationship between glove use and hand hygiene is essential for preventing healthcare-associated infections.

GLOVES ARE NOT A SUBSTITUTE FOR HAND HYGIENE: Gloves do not replace the need for hand hygiene. Healthcare workers must perform hand hygiene before donning gloves and immediately after removing gloves. Reasons gloves don't replace hand hygiene include: gloves can have microscopic holes or tears; gloves can be torn or punctured during use; hands can become contaminated during glove removal; gloves can become contaminated on the outside during use.

WHEN TO WEAR GLOVES: Wear gloves when contact with blood, body fluids, mucous membranes, non-intact skin, or contaminated surfaces is anticipated. Specific indications include: Contact Precautions (MRSA, VRE, C. difficile, etc.); performing invasive procedures; handling contaminated equipment or surfaces; cleaning and disinfection tasks; handling hazardous drugs or chemicals. Gloves should be task-specific and changed between tasks.

HAND HYGIENE BEFORE DONNING GLOVES: Always perform hand hygiene immediately before donning gloves. This prevents contamination of gloves during donning and reduces the risk of infection if gloves are torn or punctured. Use ABHS or soap and water depending on the situation (ABHS for most situations; soap and water if hands are visibly soiled).

HAND HYGIENE AFTER REMOVING GLOVES: Always perform hand hygiene immediately after removing gloves, even if gloves appear intact. Studies show that hands become contaminated during glove removal in 10-30% of cases. Contamination can occur through: microscopic holes in gloves; contamination during glove removal; touching contaminated surfaces after glove removal. Use ABHS or soap and water depending on the situation.

PROPER GLOVE REMOVAL TECHNIQUE: Remove gloves carefully to avoid hand contamination: grasp outside of one glove near wrist; peel away from hand, turning glove inside-out; hold removed glove in gloved hand; slide fingers of ungloved hand under wrist of remaining glove; peel off from inside, creating a bag for both gloves; discard gloves in waste receptacle; perform hand hygiene immediately.

CHANGING GLOVES BETWEEN TASKS: Change gloves between tasks on the same patient when moving from contaminated to clean body sites. For example, change gloves after: perineal care before providing oral care; handling contaminated wound dressings before handling IV lines; cleaning contaminated surfaces before touching clean equipment. Perform hand hygiene when changing gloves between tasks.

GLOVE USE AND THE WHO 5 MOMENTS: Glove use does not change the WHO 5 Moments for Hand Hygiene. Healthcare workers must still perform hand hygiene at all 5 moments, even when wearing gloves. For example: Moment 1 (before touching patient) - perform hand hygiene, then don gloves if indicated; Moment 2 (before aseptic procedure) - perform hand hygiene, then don sterile or clean gloves; Moment 3 (after body fluid exposure) - remove gloves, perform hand hygiene; Moment 4 (after touching patient) - remove gloves, perform hand hygiene; Moment 5 (after touching patient surroundings) - remove gloves if worn, perform hand hygiene.

EXTENDED GLOVE USE: Extended glove use (wearing the same pair of gloves for prolonged periods or for multiple patients) is not recommended. Extended glove use increases the risk of: glove tears or punctures; contamination of gloves; cross-contamination between patients; false sense of security leading to reduced hand hygiene. Change gloves between patients and between tasks as indicated.

DOUBLE GLOVING: Double gloving (wearing two pairs of gloves) is recommended for surgical procedures and other high-risk situations with increased blood exposure. Double gloving provides an additional barrier if the outer glove is punctured. If the outer glove is torn or punctured during a procedure, remove the outer glove and continue with the inner glove. Hand hygiene is still required before donning gloves and after removing all gloves.

GLOVE MATERIAL SELECTION: Choose appropriate glove material for the task: nitrile gloves for most patient care tasks (latex-free, good barrier, chemical resistant); latex gloves for surgical procedures (excellent fit and tactile sensitivity, but allergy concerns); vinyl gloves for low-risk tasks (less expensive, but lower barrier protection); specialized gloves for chemotherapy or hazardous drug handling.

GLOVE ALLERGIES: Be aware of latex allergies in healthcare workers and patients. Use latex-free gloves (nitrile or vinyl) for latex-allergic individuals. Facilities should have policies for managing latex allergies, including latex-free environments for severely allergic individuals.
keyPoints: Gloves are NOT a substitute for hand hygiene
Always perform hand hygiene before donning and after removing gloves
Wear gloves when contact with blood, body fluids, or contaminated surfaces anticipated
Hands become contaminated during glove removal in 10-30% of cases
Change gloves between tasks when moving from contaminated to clean sites
Glove use does not change WHO 5 Moments - hand hygiene still required
Extended glove use (same gloves for multiple patients) not recommended
Double gloving recommended for surgical and high-risk procedures
Choose appropriate glove material for task (nitrile, latex, vinyl)
Use latex-free gloves for latex-allergic individuals
