pages.name: Hand Skin Health & Care
content: Maintaining healthy hand skin is essential for effective hand hygiene and healthcare worker well-being. Damaged skin can harbor more microorganisms, is more difficult to clean, and can reduce hand hygiene compliance due to discomfort.

IMPACT OF HAND HYGIENE ON SKIN: Frequent hand hygiene can damage skin through: removal of natural skin oils; disruption of skin barrier function; irritation from antimicrobial agents; dryness and cracking; contact dermatitis. Healthcare workers perform hand hygiene dozens of times per shift, putting them at high risk for hand skin damage.

ABHS VS. SOAP AND WATER FOR SKIN HEALTH: Contrary to common perception, ABHS is generally LESS damaging to skin than frequent handwashing with soap and water. Reasons include: ABHS products contain emollients that moisturize skin; ABHS does not remove natural skin oils as much as soap; ABHS does not require water, which can dry skin; ABHS is faster, reducing total skin exposure time. Studies consistently show better skin tolerance with ABHS compared to frequent handwashing.

SIGNS OF HAND SKIN DAMAGE: Healthcare workers should monitor for signs of hand skin damage: dryness, roughness, or flaking; redness or irritation; cracking or fissuring; itching or burning; contact dermatitis (rash, blisters, weeping). Early recognition and treatment of skin damage is important to prevent progression and maintain hand hygiene compliance.

PREVENTING HAND SKIN DAMAGE: Strategies to prevent hand skin damage include: use ABHS instead of soap and water when possible; use hand hygiene products with emollients; apply hand lotion regularly (at least twice per shift and at end of shift); avoid hot water for handwashing (use warm or cool water); pat hands dry rather than rubbing vigorously; avoid excessive hand hygiene (perform at indicated moments, but don't over-do it); wear gloves when appropriate to reduce hand hygiene frequency.

HAND LOTION USE: Regular use of hand lotion is essential for maintaining skin health. Hand lotion recommendations: apply at least twice per shift and at the end of each shift; use facility-approved lotions that are compatible with gloves and ABHS; choose lotions with effective moisturizers (glycerin, petrolatum, dimethicone); avoid lotions with fragrances if sensitive; apply lotion after hand hygiene, not before; ensure lotion is fully absorbed before donning gloves.

LOTION COMPATIBILITY: Hand lotions must be compatible with gloves and ABHS products used in the facility. Some lotions contain petroleum-based ingredients that can degrade latex gloves. Some lotions can interfere with ABHS antimicrobial activity. Use only facility-approved hand lotions that have been tested for compatibility. Provide approved lotions at nursing stations and break rooms.

TREATMENT OF HAND DERMATITIS: If hand dermatitis develops, seek treatment promptly: consult occupational health or dermatology; use prescribed topical corticosteroids for inflammation; use barrier creams or ointments to protect damaged skin; temporarily reduce hand hygiene frequency if possible (use gloves more frequently); consider alternative hand hygiene products if current products are causing irritation; in severe cases, temporary work restrictions may be necessary.

PRODUCT SELECTION FOR SKIN HEALTH: When selecting hand hygiene products, consider skin tolerance: choose ABHS products with high emollient content; avoid products with fragrances or dyes if skin sensitivity is common; conduct user trials to assess skin tolerance; provide multiple product options if possible to accommodate individual sensitivities; regularly survey healthcare workers about skin problems and product satisfaction.

WATER TEMPERATURE: Water temperature affects skin health. Hot water removes more natural skin oils and causes more irritation than warm or cool water. Hot water does not improve antimicrobial efficacy of handwashing. Ensure handwashing sinks provide warm or cool water (60-105°F or 15-40°C), not hot water. Educate healthcare workers to avoid using hot water for handwashing.

JEWELRY AND SKIN HEALTH: Jewelry can trap moisture and irritants against skin, increasing the risk of dermatitis. Rings, watches, and bracelets should be removed before hand hygiene. Skin under rings has higher bacterial counts and is more prone to irritation. Healthcare workers with hand skin problems should avoid wearing jewelry on hands and wrists.

OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH SUPPORT: Facilities should provide occupational health support for healthcare workers with hand skin problems: screening for hand dermatitis during health assessments; prompt evaluation and treatment of skin problems; accommodation for workers with severe skin problems (alternative duties, work restrictions); education on hand skin care and prevention; access to dermatology consultation when needed.
keyPoints: Frequent hand hygiene can damage skin (dryness, irritation, dermatitis)
ABHS is generally LESS damaging to skin than frequent soap and water
Apply hand lotion regularly (at least twice per shift and at end of shift)
Use facility-approved lotions compatible with gloves and ABHS
Monitor for signs of skin damage (dryness, redness, cracking, itching)
Seek prompt treatment for hand dermatitis (occupational health, dermatology)
Choose hand hygiene products with high emollient content
Use warm or cool water for handwashing, not hot water
Remove jewelry before hand hygiene (traps moisture and irritants)
Facilities should provide occupational health support for skin problems

pages.name: Fingernails, Jewelry & Accessories
content: Fingernails, jewelry, and accessories can harbor microorganisms and interfere with effective hand hygiene. Healthcare facilities should have clear policies regarding fingernails, jewelry, and accessories for healthcare workers with direct patient contact.

NATURAL FINGERNAILS: Natural fingernails should be kept short, not extending past the fingertip. Long natural nails: harbor more microorganisms, especially under the nail; are more difficult to clean effectively during hand hygiene; are more likely to tear gloves; can scratch or injure patients. Studies show that the area under fingernails (subungual area) has the highest concentration of microorganisms on hands.

ARTIFICIAL FINGERNAILS: Artificial fingernails, extenders, wraps, and tips should NOT be worn by healthcare workers with direct patient contact, especially in high-risk areas (ICUs, operating rooms, transplant units, neonatal units). Artificial nails: harbor more microorganisms than natural nails; are associated with increased risk of healthcare-associated infections; have been implicated in multiple infection outbreaks; are more difficult to clean effectively; are more likely to tear gloves.

OUTBREAK EVIDENCE: Multiple healthcare-associated infection outbreaks have been linked to healthcare workers wearing artificial nails. Documented outbreaks include: Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections in neonatal ICU; Serratia marcescens infections in neonatal ICU; Candida infections in surgical patients; Gram-negative infections in various settings. In these outbreaks, healthcare workers with artificial nails were found to have higher bacterial counts on their hands and were implicated in pathogen transmission.

NAIL POLISH: Nail polish is generally acceptable if it is fresh and not chipped. Chipped nail polish can harbor microorganisms. Some studies suggest that freshly applied nail polish (less than 4 days old) does not increase bacterial counts on hands. However, policies vary by facility and by unit. High-risk areas may prohibit nail polish entirely. If nail polish is worn, it should be: freshly applied (less than 4 days old); not chipped or cracked; removed and reapplied regularly; light colored (easier to see dirt and contamination).

RINGS: Rings, especially rings with stones or multiple bands, harbor microorganisms and interfere with hand hygiene. Skin under rings has significantly higher bacterial counts than skin on fingers without rings. Rings can: trap dirt, organic material, and microorganisms; prevent effective hand hygiene; tear gloves; cause skin irritation. Recommendations for rings: remove all rings before hand hygiene (preferred); if rings cannot be removed, ensure thorough cleaning around and under rings; plain bands are preferable to rings with stones; limit number of rings worn.

WATCHES AND BRACELETS: Watches and bracelets should be removed before hand hygiene. They: harbor microorganisms on the band and under the watch/bracelet; prevent effective hand hygiene of wrists and forearms; can tear gloves; can scratch or injure patients. Healthcare workers should remove watches and bracelets before patient care or push them well above the wrist during hand hygiene and patient care.

FACILITY POLICIES: Healthcare facilities should have clear, written policies regarding fingernails, jewelry, and accessories. Policies should specify: maximum length for natural fingernails (typically not extending past fingertip); prohibition of artificial nails for healthcare workers with direct patient contact; restrictions on nail polish (if any); restrictions on rings, watches, and bracelets; specific requirements for high-risk areas (ICU, OR, transplant units). Policies should be enforced consistently.

EDUCATION AND ENFORCEMENT: Educate healthcare workers on the rationale for fingernail and jewelry policies: microorganism harboring; interference with hand hygiene; outbreak evidence; patient safety concerns. Enforce policies consistently through: observation and feedback; inclusion in orientation and annual competencies; leadership modeling of policies; progressive discipline for non-compliance. Explain that policies are for patient safety, not personal preference.

CULTURAL AND RELIGIOUS CONSIDERATIONS: Some healthcare workers may have cultural or religious reasons for wearing certain jewelry or maintaining long nails. Facilities should: engage in respectful dialogue about policies; explain patient safety rationale; explore accommodations when possible (e.g., alternative duties without direct patient contact); balance cultural sensitivity with patient safety; document discussions and decisions.

NAIL CARE RECOMMENDATIONS: Healthcare workers should maintain healthy nails through: regular trimming to keep nails short; cleaning under nails daily with nail brush or cleaner; avoiding nail biting or picking at cuticles (can cause breaks in skin); moisturizing nails and cuticles to prevent cracking; seeking treatment for nail infections promptly. Healthy, short natural nails are easiest to clean and safest for patients.
keyPoints: Keep natural fingernails short (not extending past fingertip)
Artificial nails should NOT be worn by healthcare workers with direct patient contact
Multiple outbreaks linked to healthcare workers with artificial nails
Nail polish acceptable if fresh (<4 days) and not chipped; policies vary by facility
Rings harbor microorganisms; remove before hand hygiene (preferred)
Remove watches and bracelets before hand hygiene
Facilities should have clear written policies on nails and jewelry
Policies especially important in high-risk areas (ICU, OR, transplant units)
